itemDescription: agriculturist, soldier, and Member of Parliament

wikipedia_page.main: Sir Owen Thomas (18 December 1858 – 6 March 1923) was a Welsh politician who served as the Member of Parliament (MP) for Anglesey.Born on Anglesey, Thomas raised the Prince of Wales Light Horse regiment to serve in the Second Boer War.  He commanded the regiment, and later became the Brigadier-General commanding the North Wales Brigade.  He also served as chief officer of the Life-Saving Apparatus at Sea section of the Board of Trade, and in his spare time bred farm stock.Thomas took an interest in politics, and stood unsuccessfully for the Liberal Party in Oswestry at the 1895 United Kingdom general election.  At the 1918 United Kingdom general election, he was elected for Anglesey as an independent labour candidate.  He joined the Labour Party group in Parliament, but resigned the party whip in 1920, and was re-elected in 1922 as an independent.  He died in 1923, causing the 1923 Anglesey by-election.He was knighted on 21 February 1917.

*Owen Thomas, Anglesey, 1919–20Elected as an "Independent Labour" MP in 1918; took the Labour Party whip in 1919 but renounced it in 1920.

link_mentions.page: List of MPs elected in the 1918 United Kingdom general election

response: At the 1922 general election he stood as a National Liberal Party candidate for Anglesey, losing by a margin of 9% to the sitting Labour MP Sir Owen Thomas.

However, Owen Thomas died in January 1923, and at the resulting by-election in April Robert Thomas won a 3-way contest with 53% of the votes, and a 23% majority over the second-placed Labour candidate.F W S Craig, British Parliamentary Election Results 1918-1949; Political Reference Publications, Glasgow 1949

response: :3Sir Owen Thomas had been elected as Independent Labour, took the whip for a while, before reverting to Independent Labour.

*Owen Thomas (automobile company), founded in 1908 in Janesville, Wisconsin
He was narrowly defeated at Anglesey in the 1918 general election by the Labour candidate Owen Thomas.  He then unsuccessfully contested the University of Wales constituency in 1922.

A war memorial in the village square records those from the village who died in both world wars, three sons of Brigadier-General Owen Thomas of Brynddu, who headed Lloyd George's Welsh Army.Llanfechell War Memorial
The by-election was caused by the death of the sitting Labour MP, Sir Owen Thomas on 17 January 1923. He had been MP here since winning the seat in 1918.
